subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Which lexical set is the second vowel of _because_ in?
msgSnippet: ... But is that really true, or just an assumption of yours? ... If so, then yes. ... Ah.  I hadn t thought of spelling reduced forms as such, any more than TO
messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:

> I know that. My point was that since the forms with
> stressed /V/ go back to forms with other checked vowels by
> way of unstressed /@/

But is that really true, or just an assumption of yours?

> it may be advisable to spell these
> words according to the 'historical' pronunciations with
> un-destressed vowels, at least as long as these
> pronunciations actually survive with some speakers.

If so, then yes.

> > The /@m/ pronunciation of the latter is not a reduction but a
> > separate lexeme < OE _hem_.
>
> As I hope you suspected I know that. However the form /@m/
> *functions* as the reduced form of /DEm/, the reduced /D@m/
> while existing being used only in more formal styles for
> many speakers of English. But my main point is that we
> would prefer to distinguish the reduced forms of //him// and
> //hem// in spelling as {Im} and {Em}, notwithstanding that
> they arent actually pronounced so.

Ah. I hadn't thought of spelling reduced forms as such,
any more than TO does. But since 'em is the reduced form
of hem, I'd spell it hem.

--
Man has no body distinct from his soul, John Cowan
for that called body is a portion of the soul cowan@...
discerned by the five senses, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
the chief inlets of the soul in this age. --William Blake

Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:

> I know that.  My point was that since the forms with
> stressed /V/ go back to forms with other checked vowels by
> way of unstressed /@/

But is that really true, or just an assumption of yours?

> it may be advisable to spell these
> words according to the 'historical' pronunciations with
> un-destressed vowels, at least as long as these 
> pronunciations actually survive with some speakers.

If so, then yes.

> > The /@m/ pronunciation of the latter is not a reduction but a
> > separate lexeme < OE _hem_.
> 
> As I hope you suspected I know that.  However the form /@m/
> *functions* as the reduced form of /DEm/, the reduced /D@m/
> while existing being used only in more formal styles for
> many speakers of English.  But my main point is that we
> would prefer to distinguish the reduced forms of //him// and
> //hem// in spelling as {Im} and {Em}, notwithstanding that
> they arent actually pronounced so.  

Ah.  I hadn't thought of spelling reduced forms as such,
any more than TO does.  But since 'em is the reduced form
of hem, I'd spell it hem.
